messageBody:
> I'm testing with databases right now and it's in fact very
tricky. I'm not
> using mock objects and directly test with the database. The
reason is that I
> test a database access layer, so I really need to test with the
databases I support.

But we use a framework which another company offers. They have base
classes and
base components which provide persistance to the database layer.

We create components by using their base classes and base
components. If we don't use
mock objects then we test implicitly their framework. But this
company tests their
framework (which includes the database layer) already.

> I believe that you have to test with the database anyway so I
would at least
> have some integration tests that are using the databases directly.

Okay. I think this can be done by providing the real object instead
of the mock
object.

> I would first present JUnit and set up Continuous Integration (or
a nightly
> build). Once the developers are more confident in their tests,
you can
> introduce TDD. I don't think that TDD is a requirement for good
software.
> Tests definitively are.

I must wait and see.

> I would also introduce Eclipse/PMD and check out the errors in the
code.

We already use Eclipse. What is PMD? A plugin?

> -Vladimir
